title: Calculate monthly commision amount based on criteria
content: Hi Team,I want to calculate commission amount starting from Jan'25 till Dec'25. I have data with loan_officer names with their monthly loan_counts. I want to calculate their commission amount based on a given criteria range.To calculate commission amount the criteria is : 1. if loan_counts<=50 then loan_count*$1502.if loan_counts>50 and loan_counts<=80 then loan_count*$2003 if loan_counts> 80 then loan_counts*$300Here loan_counts are calculating based on cummaltive-sum. E.g. Loan officer A monthly loan_counts are: Jan=20,Feb=25,Mar=20,Apr=20.if we calculate commission amount for Jan based on given criteria then Jan=20*$150 (Since loan-counts<=50 then multiply by $150)For Feb=25*$150 (Since total_loan_counts<=50 because till feb we have 20+25=45 which is <=50)Mar=20 units (total loan_counts= 20+25+20=65 till Mar which is >50 then , for Mar commission amount =5*$150+15*$200=750+3000=$3750Apr=20 units (total loan_counts= 20+25+20+20=85 till Apr which is >80 , for Apr commission amount = 15*200+5*300=$4500 (since out of 20 units,15 units falls under <=80 unit and remaining 5 units falls >80 so that's why 15*200+5*300)We required output with two fields only along with month filterAdded snapshot for output.E.g. for Apr month: A's commission amount : 15*200+5*300=4500﻿B's commission amount: 14*200+6*300=4600Added Working Tableau workbook.Thanks!
best_answer: @Mohit Tyagi(Member)​ Because you calculation is using a table calculation function, you cannot use a dimension filter (seeThe Tableau Order of Operations - The Flerlage Twins: Analytics, Data Visualization, and Tableau)You can create a table calculation filter using the LOOKUP function with an offset of 0.//F_Lookup DateLOOKUP(ATTR(DATE(DATETRUNC('month',[Date-Close]))),0)Because the calculation is relying on the Month to determine the cumulative total, Month must be in the view so you can 'Compute using' it for the table calculation.When working within one year, either MONTH or MY will work.  When you start crossing years, you will need YEAR separate from MONTH.

best_answer: Clicking on your bar changes the content of a calculated field from being the category to the sub-category. So, when you click on Furniture, and the chart switches to the subcategories, because you are still trying to filter on a value of "Furniture", there are no values, and so the filtering gets reset. It wouldn't really make sense to filter the other charts to Furniture and no longer be displaying furniture (in my opinion), so one way to fix your problem is to switch your drilldown action to be on Menu, rather than Select, then clicking on a category (or subcategory) will filter the other charts, but you'll have to click on a menu entry (in the tooltip) to switch the bottom bar chart between category and subcategory:

title: Add new dates to an existing data set
content: See the attached sample:each employee has existing Vest Share dates along with associated vest share quantityI created a date parameterI created a shares to be spent paramaterThe idea here is to allocate the new shares to each employee (they have a ratio that needs to be multiplied by the total shares to be spentThe BIG CHALLENGE:I need to set up the date parameter to whatever date I need including a date that is NOT currently in the vest date schedule.For example, if I select June of 2026 and I want to distribute 1,200 new shares (and assuming 3 year vesting), I would need to see for Joe:80 shares in June 202780 shares in June 202880 shares in June 2029For Mary:320 shares in JUne 2027320 shares in June 2028320 shares in June 2029I have tried to extend the date range on month(vest date) but any calculated fields I do remain blank as if the extension of date is fake data and tableau is ignoring any of my calculated fields.Thank youNick
best_answer: I had some spare time, decided to try an tackle this...bit involved.1) Jim's absolutely correct that you'll need to scaffold in the missing date (months/years) as Tableau Desktop won't make that up for you.  Using the feature of displaying missing rows/columns sometimes works, but not in this case; and, keyword 'display'.  Tableau will display missing months but there's no values associated with it, and even if there were, they'd be displayed values as well, not real values to work with.2) I exported your data as .csv because I couldn't get to the data via the Data Source tab of your workbook.  That was then connected to using Tableau Prep.  Only one initial change to your data was to create a new field to normalize Vested Date to "month" using MAKEDATE() function:MAKEDATE(YEAR([VestDate]),MONTH([VestDate]),1)3) In MS-Excel, created a new single column of consecutive dates at the Month-Year level of detail.  All the way out to 12/1/2029:4) Connected to it in Tableau Prep, then joined it to your data using the following (note the join operator is <=) with an Inner Join:5) Then an Aggregation Step to reduce down the amount of rows that are created as a result of this join (selected only on Mary's data in this view):6) Then bring back in the Vested Dates via a Left-join on Vested Date and Month-Year date, Name, and ID:7) Then an Output Step as .hyper extract for use in Desktop.  The rest that follows is in Desktop in a new workbook.  The dates now rely on the new Month-Year date, not your Vested Date. A new calculation which is used as a 'bridge' calc.  It's referenced in the next calculation following.  Called it# of Additional Shares:{FIXED[Name]:SUM({FIXED[Name],[Month-Year]:(IF MONTH(MIN([Month-Year]))=MONTH([Dateto be distributed])AND YEAR(MIN([Month-Year]))>YEAR(MIN([Dateto be distributed]))THEN1END)})}8) Modified theAdditional Shares calcas:IF MONTH(MIN([Month-Year]))=MONTH([Dateto be distributed])AND YEAR(MIN([Month-Year]))>YEAR(MIN([Dateto be distributed]))THEN(SUM({FIXED[Name]:AVG([Sharesto spend])*AVG([Ratio])}))END/SUM([#ofAdditionalShares])9) Put it altogether and you'd have:So that, when a date is selected in the 'Date to be distributed' parameter, the results from the calc's above are assigned to the month'safter the current year selected in that parameter.Example workbook .twbx format attached.Best, Don Wise -Please don’t forget toupvote and/or Select as Bestby clicking the hyperlink belowin the response that answered your question.

title: How do I include a space in a column chart of Likert scale data for scores that were never chosen?
content: Basically I have a few Likert scale survey questions that I want to analyze, but when I throw them into a bar chart sometimes there is a number missing because the survey respondents never chose that option. How do I leave a space for that value in my chart?
best_answer: If you're looking to create a score (and related question dimension) that doesn't currently exist in the dataset, then you'll need to bring that in separately by scaffolding in related data.  The below usesnot Tableau Desktop but Tableau Prep to clean/reshape the data:1) Create a MS-Excel worksheet of just the question(s) and the range of possible scores:2) Pivot the questions in Tableau Prep so that it's tall not wide, then join the result on Question and on Score (from your data) to Answer Scale (score),  The initial result would then reveal that Current Satisfaction and Price Importance are unmatched to the Answer Scale:But that doesn't create thenullcondition that you need which would then create two new rows (1) Current Satisfaction (2) Price Importance.  By changing the join from inner to a Right Join, you'll then see the two new rows created with the other column values being NULL:From there a bit of clean up to remove non-needed columns, and the Output Step is added (can be an output of .csv or .xlsx or .hyper (extract) or written to another DB) which is then used in Desktop.  The output results look like:3) Then take the Output of that (I used a .hyper extract) into Desktop:The Tableau Prep flow (packaged) is attached to help point the way.  If you don't have Prep, it is a free download which uses the same licensing as Desktop (comes with your subscription).Best, Don Wise -Please don’t forget toupvote and/or Select as Bestby clicking the hyperlink belowin the response that answered your question.

title: Is there any way to retrieve the list of Suspended subscriptions from the Postgres?. Any help in the issue is much appreciated.
best_answer: Hi@Vijay Bala(Member)​Sorry, looks like I did read it to fast.As Matt Coles correctly states in the upper link, the only way would be to go down the REST API road.I have built a monitoring script to spot extracts that had a failure in the first run (consequtive fails number = 0) to retrigger the extract refresh. It is the method get extract refresh tasks.https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_ref_jobs_tasks_and_schedules.htm#get_extract_refresh_tasksYou query all extract refresh tasks that have a number of consecutiveFailedCount equal to 0.https://help.tableau.com/current/api/rest_api/en-us/REST/rest_api_ref_jobs_tasks_and_schedules.htm#run_extract_refresh_taskThen you store the LUID of those and iterate through that list to trigger the rerun.Plus, I used the repository data sources (second link) to build an alert system for the extract refreshes that failed at least twice (consequtive fails number >= 1) and managed to get the failure note. Plus I also built a helper tool having collected some of the errors and pointing to the knowledge base articles.Unfortunately I did this for a client and have no access to the system as I don't work for the customer at the time being.It's a little bit of work, especially the refresh-triggering script. But it is worth it to monitor extract refreshes. Also you can note whoever you want not just the owner. The customer still loves me for having built this.Best regards,Matthias

title: Rounding Up or Down in Tableau
content: Hi, I'm using Tableau's custom number format option to scale by a thousand in such a way that 1200000 ends up as "1 200":The problem I'm facing is that when there is a number such as 1400706, it always rounds down instead of to the nearest thousand. So I end up getting "1 400" instead of 1 401", which would be more accurate.Is there any way to force it to the nearest thousand using the custom format option?I figured there's no point in attaching a workbook as you literally just need any large, random number.Thanks!
best_answer: That's actually the problem I was having, as Idon'twant it to do that type of rounding. However, it turns out it was rounding perfectly fine (to the nearest 1,000 as desired). Once we looked deeper into the numbers, we realized that we had the following issue:Scaled values: 15, 7 and a total of 21 (so we assumed it was rounding down)Original values: 14 563, 6 854 and 21 417So actually it was rounding correctly, it's just that totaled, it was closer to 21 then 22, because the rounding was only applied once summed. Which is obviously logical, we just missed that on our end. So problem solved!

content: Hi all,I'm trying to create a line graph showing Day on Day data for a custom selected period (based on Start and End date params) + another line graph overlay showing data for the same period shifted -1 month.The closest functioning solution I found is this (-1 year in this example but function is the same):https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=86mnN3d021EHowever, these labels don't work for data periods exceeding 1 month, as labels exclude any overlaps (ex. custom period 01/03/25 - 14/04/25 will only label the previous period as 01/02/25 - 28/02/25 instead of 01/02/25 - 14/03/25).I've been researching this for some time and still haven't found a solution which would enable comparison with overlapping dates.Any help would be appreciated, thanks!

title: Refresh Extract of multiple connection source containing a static geospatial file in Tableau Online
content: Hi everyone,I have created an extract in Tableau Desktop, that takes data from two different sources, from a connection to mysql server and from a "static" geospatial file (saved locally). I upload the workbook to tableau online and everything seems to be perfect. However, the problems occurs when it comes to refreshing the extract. The extract is not refreshed, even though there is no error alert returned by tableau online when I try to refresh it manually. The connection to mysql server is functional, because I tested it when I uploaded the workbook. I assume there is a problem with a geospatial file. However, the geospatial file is included as an external file when I upload the workbook and there is no need to be updated. What do you think? Is there a workaround on this?
